{{Year nav topic5|1539|literature}} This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1539'''. ==Events== *April – Printing of the [[Great Bible]] (''The Byble in Englyshe'') is completed and it is distributed to churches in England.<ref>{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Alan|author2=Veronica|year=1992|title=The Chronology of British History|publisher=Century Ltd|location=London|pages=145–148|isbn=0-7126-5616-2}}</ref> Prepared by [[Myles Coverdale]], it contains much material from the [[Tyndale Bible]] (unacknowledged as this version is officially considered heretical). *''Unknown dates'' **Game Place House in [[Great Yarmouth]] becomes the first premises in England to be used regularly as a public theatre.<ref>{{cite book|first=Patrick|last=Robertson|title=The Shell Book of Firsts|location=London|publisher=Ebury Press|year=1974|isbn=0-7181-1279-2|page=189}}</ref> **[[Marie Dentière]] writes an open letter to [[Marguerite de Navarre|Marguerite of Navarre]], sister of King [[Francis I of France]]; the ''Epistre tres utile'', or "very useful letter", calls for an expulsion of Catholic clergy from France. **The first printing press in [[North America]] is set up in [[Mexico City]]. The first known book from it, ''Manual de Adultos'', appears in 1540.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Press in Colonial America|work=A Publisher’s History of American Magazines — Background and Beginnings|url=http://www.themagazinist.com/uploads/Part_4_Colonial_Printers_and_Papers.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=2013-08-22}}</ref> **Teseo Ambrogio's ''Introductio in Chaldaicam lingua, Syriaca atq Armenica, & dece alias linguas'', published in [[Pavia]], introduces several [[Middle East]]ern languages to [[Western Europe]] for the first time.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Robert Estienne]] – ''Alphabetum Hebraicum'' *[[Martin Luther]] – ''[[On the Councils and the Church]]''
===Poetry=== {{Main|1539 in poetry}}
==Births== *[[February 27]] – [[Franciscus Raphelengius]], Flemish-born Dutch scholar, printer and bookseller (died [[1597 in literature|1597]])<ref>{{nl icon}} [http://www.dbnl.org/tekst/_jaa002186601_01/_jaa002186601_01_0012.htm Some biographical information]</ref> *[[March 5]] – [[Christoph Pezel]], German theologian (died [[1604 in literature|1604]]) *[[April 12]] – [[Garcilaso de la Vega (chronicler)|Garcilaso de la Vega]], Spanish Peruvian ''[[mestizo]]'' chronicler (died [[1616 in literature|1616]]) *[[December 5]] – [[Fausto Paolo Sozzini]], Italian theologian (died [[1604 in literature|1604]]) *[[December 20]] – [[Paulus Melissus]], German writer in Latin, translator and composer (died [[1602 in literature|1602]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Olivier de Serres]], French writer on agriculture and horticulture (died [[1619 in literature|1619]]) **[[Jean de Tournes (1539–1615)|Jean de Tournes]], French author, printer and bookseller (died [[1615 in literature|1615]]) **[[Richard White of Basingstoke]], English jurist and historian (died [[1611 in literature|1611]])
==Deaths== *[[March 5]] – [[Kaspar Ursinus Velius]], German scholar, poet and historian (born c. 1493) *[[May 7]] – [[Ottaviano Petrucci]], Italian printer (born [[15th century in literature|1466]]) *[[July 5]] – Saint [[Anthony Maria Zaccaria]], Italian religious writer and leader of the Counter-reformation (born [[16th century in literature|1502]])<ref>[http://www.barnabites.com/stanthonyzaccaria St. Anthony Mary's biography and his writings page on the Barnabite Fathers' North American website]</ref> *[[August 10]] – [[Lanspergius]], German Carthusian monk and ascetic writer (born [[15th century in literature|1489]]) *[[November 25]] – [[Johann Alexander Brassicanus]], German author and teacher (died c. 1500) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Ferdinand Columbus]], Spanish bibliographer and cosmographer (born [[15th century in literature|1488]]) **[[Gabriel Alonso de Herrera]], Spanish author of an agricultural treatise (born [[15th century in literature|1470]])
==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1539]] [[Category:1539 books]] [[Category:16th-century books| ]] [[Category:Renaissance literature]] [[Category:Early Modern literature]] [[Category:Years of the 16th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1588|music}}
== Events == * [[8 July]] – [[Thomas Morley]] received the degree Bachelor of Music from Oxford University * [[Ferdinando I de' Medici, Grand Duke of Tuscany|Ferdinando de' Medici]] appoints [[Emilio de' Cavalieri]] artistic superintendent of the Medici court in Florence
== Publications == *[[William Byrd]] – ''Psalms, Sonnets and Songs of Sadness and Pietie'', London *[[Giaches de Wert]] – Ninth book of [[Madrigal (music)|madrigals]] ''a''5 *[[Nicholas Yonge]] (pub.) – ''[[Musica transalpina]]'', London *The Walsingham Consort Books are copied, probably by [[Daniel Bacheler]], who was only 15 or 16 years old at the time and contributed seven of his own pieces to this collection for [[broken consort]]
== Classical music == * [[Krzysztof Klabon]] – ''Pieśni Kalliopy Slowieńskiey: na terażnieysze pod Byczyną zwycięstwo'', a [[Song cycle|cycle of six songs]] for voice and lute to texts by [[Stanisław Grochowski]], celebrating the [[Battle of Byczyna]], which ended the [[War of the Polish Succession (1587–88)|War of the Polish Succession]]
== Births == *[[June 9]] ''(bapt.)'' – [[Johann Andreas Herbst]], German composer and music theorist (d. 1666) *[[June 30]] - [[Giovanni Maria Sabino]], Italian organist and composer (d. 1649) *[[September 10]] ''(bapt.)'' – [[Nicholas Lanier]], English lutenist and composer (d. 1666) *[[September 8]] – [[Marin Mersenne]], French mathematician and music theorist (d. 1648)
== Deaths == *[[August 12]] – [[Alfonso Ferrabosco (I)]], composer (b. 1543)
[[Category:1588|Music]] [[Category:16th century in music]] [[Category:Years in music]]

{{Year nav topic5|1613|literature}}
This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1613'''.
==Events== *At the English royal court, January and February see massive celebrations for the marriage of [[Frederick V, Elector Palatine]] to [[James I of England|King James]]'s daughter [[Elizabeth Stuart, Queen of Bohemia|Princess Elizabeth]], culminating in their wedding on [[February 14]]. **During the court festivities in the winter of 1612–13, the [[King's Men (playing company)|King's Men]] give twenty performances, which include eight Shakespeare plays, four by [[Beaumont and Fletcher]], and the lost ''[[Cardenio]]''. **In early January, the [[Children of the Chapel|Children of the Queen's Revels]] give two performances of Beaumont and Fletcher's ''[[Cupid's Revenge]]''. **On [[January 11]], the [[playing company]] that had been the [[Admiral's Men]], then Prince Henry's Men, becomes the Elector Palatine's (or Palsgrave's) Men. **On [[February 15]], ''[[The Memorable Masque of the Middle Temple and Lincoln's Inn]]'', written by [[George Chapman]] and designed by [[Inigo Jones]], is staged in the Great Hall of the [[Palace of Whitehall]]. [[Francis Beaumont]]'s ''[[The Masque of the Inner Temple and Gray's Inn]]'' follows five days later on [[February 20]]. **On [[February 25]], The [[Lady Elizabeth's Men]] perform [[John Marston (poet)|Marston]]'s ''[[The Dutch Courtesan]]'' at Court. (They repeat it at the end of the year, on December 12.) **On [[February 27]], The Queen's Revels Children act [[George Chapman|Chapman]]'s ''[[The Widow's Tears]]''. **Early in March, Frederick and [[Charles I of England|Prince Charles]] visit the [[University of Cambridge]] where they see performances of [[Samuel Brooke]]'s Latin plays ''Adelphe'' and ''Scyros''. **English poet [[Francis Quarles]] attends the newly-married Queen on her progress to Continental Europe. *[[June 8]] – The King's Men re-play ''[[Cardenio]]'' at Court. *[[June 29]] – The [[Globe Theatre]] burns down during a performance of ''[[Henry VIII (play)|Henry VIII]]''. *Publication in London of [[Elizabeth Cary, Lady Falkland]]'s [[closet drama]] ''[[The Tragedy of Mariam|The Tragedy of Mariam, the Fair Queen of Jewry]]'' (written 1602–4), the first original dramatic work in English known to have been published by a woman, and acknowledged as such ("Written by that learned, vertuous, and truly noble Ladie, E. C."). *[[Cyril Tourneur]] is paid £10 for delivering letters from the [[Stuart Dynasty|Stuart]] monarchy to Brussels.
==New books== <!-- (''Title of published book translation''), ("Title of published poem/story translation"), (Literal translation of title) --> ===Prose=== *[[Miguel de Cervantes]] – ''[[Novelas ejemplares|Exemplary Novels]]'' *[[Thomas Dekker (poet)|Thomas Dekker]] – ''A Strange Horse Race'' *[[Samuel Purchas]] – ''Purchas, his Pilgrimage; or, Relations of the World and the Religions observed in all Ages'' *[[Mark Ridley (physician)|Mark Ridley]] – ''A Short Treatise of Magneticall Bodies and Motions'' *Sir [[Anthony Shirley]] – ''Sir Anthony Shirley: his Relation of his Travels into Persia'' *[[Alexander Whitaker]] – ''Good Newes from Virginia'' *[[George Wither]] – ''Abuses Stript, and Whipt'' (satires)
===Drama=== *Anonymous – ''Heteroclitanomalonomia'' *[[Giovan Battista Andreini]] – ''L'Adamo'' *[[Francis Beaumont]] **''[[The Knight of the Burning Pestle]]'' published **''[[The Masque of the Inner Temple and Gray's Inn]]'' *[[Beaumont and Fletcher]] – ''The Honest Man's Fortune'' *[[Samuel Brooke]] – ''Adelphe'' and ''Scyros'' (in Latin) *[[Thomas Campion]] **''The Lords' Masque'' **''The Somerset Masque'' *[[Elizabeth Cary, Lady Falkland]] – ''[[The Tragedy of Mariam]]'' *[[George Chapman]] **''[[The Memorable Masque of the Middle Temple and Lincoln's Inn]]'' **''[[The Revenge of Bussy D'Ambois]]'' published *[[Lope de Vega]] **''[[La dama boba]]'' (The Foolish Lady) **''[[The Dog in the Manger (play)|El perro del hortelano]]'' (The Dog in the Manger) **''San Diego de Alcalá'' *[[Thomas Heywood]] **''The Silver Age'' (published) **''The Brazen Age'' (published) *[[Ben Jonson]] (masques) **''A Challenge at Tilt, at a Marriage'' **''The Irish Masque at Court'' *[[John Marston (poet)|John Marston]] and William Barksted – ''[[The Insatiate Countess]]'' (published) *[[Thomas Middleton]] – ''[[A Chaste Maid in Cheapside]]'' *[[William Shakespeare]] – ''[[Henry VIII (play)|Henry VIII]]'' * Shakespeare and [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] (attributed) – ''[[The History of Cardenio]]''
===Poetry=== {{main|1613 in poetry}} *[[William Drummond of Hawthornden]] – ''Tears on the Death of Moeliades''
==Births== *[[February 11]] – [[Henry Killigrew (playwright)|Henry Killigrew]], English dramatist (died [[1700 in literature|1700]]) *April – [[Franciscus Plante]], Dutch poet (died [[1690 in literature|1690]]) *[[June 16]] – [[John Cleveland]], English poet (died [[1658 in literature|1658]]) *[[August 15]] **[[Gilles Ménage]], French classicist and historian (died [[1692 in literature|1692]]) **[[Jeremy Taylor]], English writer and cleric (died [[1667 in literature|1667]]) *[[September 15]] – [[François de La Rochefoucauld (writer)|François de La Rochefoucauld]], French writer of maxims and memoirs (died [[1680 in literature|1680]]) *[[November 5]] – [[Isaac de Benserade]], French poet (died [[1691 in literature|1691]]) *''Probable year of birth'' – [[Richard Crashaw]], English poet (died [[1667 in literature|1667]])
==Deaths== *[[January 28]] – Sir [[Thomas Bodley]], English founder of the [[Bodleian Library]] (born [[1545 in literature|1545]]) *[[February 16]] – [[Mikalojus Daukša]], [[Lithuania]]n religious writer and translator (born c. 1527) *[[August 18]] – [[Giovanni Artusi]], Italian music theorist (born c. 1540) *[[August 21]] – [[Natshinnaung]], [[Toungoo dynasty|Toungoo]] prince, poet and musician (executed, born [[1578 in literature|1578]]) *[[August 26]] – [[George Owen of Henllys|George Owen]], Welsh antiquarian (born [[1552 in literature|1552]]) *[[September 15]] – Sir [[Thomas Overbury]], English poet and essayist (probably poisoned, born [[1581 in literature|1581]]) *[[October 9]] – [[Henry Constable]], English Catholic polemicist and poet (born [[1562 in literature|1562]]) *[[October 22]] – [[Mathurin Régnier]], French satirist (born [[1573 in literature|1573]]) *[[November 16]] – [[Trajano Boccalini]], Italian satirist (born [[1556 in literature|1556]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1613 books| ]] [[Category:Years in literature]] [[Category:Years of the 17th century in literature]]

{{Year nav topic5|1966|film|television|radio }} {{Years in film}}<!-- SIDEBAR NAV-BOX --> The year '''1966 in film''' involved some significant events. ''[[A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)|A Man for All Seasons]]'' won six [[Academy Awards]], including Best Picture.
==Events== * October 19 - [[Gulf and Western Industries]] acquire [[Paramount Pictures]]. * November - [[Seven Arts Productions]] reach agreement to acquire [[Warner Bros.]] for $32 million, later forming a new company [[Warner Bros.-Seven Arts]]. * December 15 - Entertainment pioneer [[Walt Disney]], best known for his creation of [[Mickey Mouse]], breakthroughs in the field of [[animation]], [[filmmaking]], [[theme park]] design and other achievements, dies at the age of 65. He died while he was producing ''[[The Jungle Book (1967 film)|The Jungle Book]]'', ''[[The Happiest Millionaire]]'', and ''[[Winnie the Pooh and the Blustery Day]]''; the last three films under his personal supervision.

== Awards ==
'''[[39th Academy Awards|Academy Awards]]:'''
:[[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]]: '''''[[A Man for All Seasons (1966 film)|A Man for All Seasons]]''''' - Highland, Columbia :[[Academy Award for Directing|Best Director]]: '''[[Fred Zinnemann]]''' - ''A Man for All Seasons'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]]: '''[[Paul Scofield]]''' - ''A Man for All Seasons'' :[[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]]: '''[[Elizabeth Taylor]]''' - ''[[Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor|Best Supporting Actor]]: '''[[Walter Matthau]]''' - ''[[The Fortune Cookie]]'' :[[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]]: '''[[Sandy Dennis]]''' - ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' :[[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film|Best Foreign Language Film]]: '''''[[A Man and a Woman]]''''' (''Un homme et une femme''), directed by [[Claude Lelouch]], France
'''[[BAFTA]] Film Awards:'''
:Best Film from any Source: '''''[[Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? (film)|Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?]]''''' :Best British film: '''''[[The Spy Who Came in from the Cold (film)|The Spy Who Came in from the Cold]]'''''
'''[[24th Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Awards]]:'''
:<u>'''Drama:'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama|Best Picture]]: '''''A Man for All Seasons''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor]]: '''Paul Scofield''' – ''A Man for All Seasons'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actress]]: '''[[Anouk Aimée]]''' – ''A Man and a Woman''
:<u>'''Musical or comedy:'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Best Picture]]: '''''[[The Russians Are Coming, the Russians Are Coming]]''''' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor]]: '''[[Alan Arkin]]''' – ''The Russians are Coming, the Russians are Coming'' :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actress]]: '''[[Lynn Redgrave]]''' – ''[[Georgy Girl]]''
:<u>'''Other'''</u> :[[Golden Globe Award for Best Director – Motion Picture|Best Director]]: '''Fred Zinnemann''' – ''A Man for All Seasons''
'''[[Palme d'Or]] (Cannes Film Festival):''' :'''''[[A Man and a Woman]]''''' (''Un homme et une femme''), directed by [[Claude Lelouch]], France :'''''[[Signore & Signori]]''''' (''The Birds, the Bees and the Italians''), directed by [[Pietro Germi]], Italy
'''Italian National Syndicate of Film Journalists''', Location: Italy
'''[[Silver Ribbon]]''' *Best Actor winner in ''[[Questa volta parliamo di uomini]]'' (This Time Let's Talk about Men): [[Nino Manfredi]] **Nominee in ''[[The 10th Victim]]'': [[Marcello Mastroianni]] **A third nominee was not determined. *Best Actress winner in ''[[La fuga (1964 film)|La fuga]]'': [[Giovanna Ralli]] **Nominees in ''Juliet of the Spirits'': [[Giulietta Masina]] and in ''[[The Mandrake]]'': [[Rosanna Schiaffino]] *Best Supporting Actor winner in ''[[I Knew Her Well]]'': [[Ugo Tognazzi]] **Nominees in ''The Mandrake'': [[Totò]] and [[Romolo Valli]] *Best Supporting Actress winner in ''Juliet of the Spirits'': [[Sandra Milo]] **Nominee in ''[[Made in Italy (film)|Made in Italy]]'' [[Anna Magnani]] **A third nominee was not determined. *Best Director winner in ''I Knew Her Well'': [[Antonio Pietrangeli]] **Nominees in ''[[Fists in the Pocket]]'': [[Marco Bellocchio]] and in ''Juliet of the Spirits'': [[Federico Fellini]] *Best Foreign Director winner in ''[[The Servant (1963 film)|The Servant]]'': [[Joseph Losey]] **Nominees in ''[[Hamlet (1964 film)]]: [[Grigori Kozintsev]] and in ''[[King and Country]]'': Joseph Losey *Best Screenplay winner in ''I Knew Her Well'': [[Ettore Scola]], [[Antonio Pietrangeli]] and [[Ruggero Maccari]] **Nominees in ''Fists in the Pocket'': [[Marco Bellocchio]] and in ''[[Sandra (film)|Sandra]]'': [[Suso Cecchi D'Amico]], [[Enrico Medioli]], [[Luchino Visconti]] *Best Cinematography, B/W winner in ''Sandra'': [[Armando Nannuzzi]] *Best Cinematography, Color winner in ''[[Juliet of the Spirits]]'': [[Gianni di Venanzo]]. In memory of. *Best Costume Design winner in ''Juliet of the Spirits'': [[Piero Gherardi]] *Best Score winner in ''[[Seven Golden Men]]'': [[Armando Trovajoli]] *Best Producer - Short Film winner in ''[[Con il cuore fermo Sicilia]]'': [[Clodio Cinematografica]] *Best Short Film winner in [[Antonio Ligabue, pittore]]'': [[Raffaele Andreassi]] *Best Original Story winner in ''Fists in the Pocket'': [[Marco Bellocchio]] **Nominees in ''I Knew Her Well'': [[Ruggero Maccari]], Ettore Scola, [[Antonio Pietrangeli]] and in ''Seven Golden Men'': [[Marco Vicario]] *Best Producer winner in ''Seven Golden Men'': Marco Vicario **Nominee in ''Fists in the Pocket'': [[Enzo Doria]] **A third nominee was not determined. *Best Production Design winner in ''Juliet of the Spirits'': [[Piero Gherardi]].

{{Infobox Artwork | title = A Negress | image_file = Murzynka - Anna Bilińska-Bohdanowiczowa.jpg | artist = [[Anna Bilińska-Bohdanowicz]] | year = 1884 | medium = [[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]] | height_metric = 63 | width_metric = 48.8 | metric_unit = cm | imperial_unit = in | city = [[Warsaw]] | museum = [[National Museum, Warsaw|National Museum]] }} '''''A Negress''''' ({{lang-pl|[[Murzyn|Murzynka]]}}) is an 1884 realistic portrait study [[oil painting]] on canvas by the Polish artist [[Anna Bilińska-Bohdanowicz]]. During [[World War II]], the painting was stolen; it was recovered in 2012.<ref name="museum">{{cite web|title=A Negress|url=http://muzeumutracone.pl/en/portfolio/a-negress/|publisher=Lost Museum|accessdate=21 December 2013}}</ref>
==Description== The picture was painted in oil technique in 1884 in [[Paris]]. It is a portrait of a black woman located on a light background. She is shown from waist up, dressed in a white robe, but is part naked, exposing a breast. She wears a gold necklace, and a red head scarf. This type of painting of an exotic person was a popular topic in the late nineteenth century. The canvas is signed in the upper right corner with the painter's family name and date of creation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Negress Back in the National Museum|url=http://dzieje.pl/kultura-i-sztuka/odnaleziony-obraz-murzynka-wraca-do-muzeum-narodowego|publisher=Dzieje.pl|accessdate=21 December 2013}}</ref>
==History== The painting originally belonged to the collector Dominik Witke-Jeżewski, who deposited the canvas at the [[National Museum, Warsaw|National Museum in Warsaw]] in 1933. In 1939, the painting was purchased by the Museum for 700 [[złoty]]s. During World War II, the painting was stolen in unknown circumstances, and since 1945 was sought by the Poles. In 2011, the painting appeared at an auction in Germany. It was recovered thanks to the effort of the [[Ministry of Culture and National Heritage (Poland)|Ministry of Culture and National Heritage]] and the support of the Kronenberg Foundation of Citi Handlowy Bank. Since 2012 the picture is once more displayed at the Warsaw National Museum.<ref name="museum"/>
==See also== *[[Looted art]] *[[World War II looting of Poland]]

Aesop Rock and the Olympia Free Choir| publisher = SomeKindofAwesome.com| accessdate = November 2, 2011}}</ref> *keyboard *bass guitar<ref>{{cite web| last = Angle | first = Merrick | title = Aesop Rock’s Home Recording Methods | work = | publisher= emusician.com| url = http://www.emusician.com/how-to/1334/aesop-rocks-home-recording-methods/39173}}</ref> *[[Music sequencer|sequencer]] *[[Music Production Center|MPC]] }} | years_active = 1996–present |label = {{flatlist| *[[Definitive Jux]] *[[Mush Records|Mush]] *[[Rhymesayers]] *[[Stones Throw]] }} | associated_acts = {{flatlist| *[[The Weathermen (hip hop group)|The Weathermen]] *[[The Uncluded]] *[[Hail Mary Mallon]] *[[Blockhead (music)|Blockhead]] *[[Rob Sonic]] *[[Onry Ozzborn]] *[[El-P]] *[[Mr. Lif]] *[[Cage (rapper)|Cage]] *[[Slug (rapper)|Slug]] *[[Kimya Dawson]] *[[Felt (hip hop)|Felt]] *[[Homeboy Sandman]] }} }}
'''Ian Matthias Bavitz''' (born June 5, 1976), better known by his stage name '''Aesop Rock''', is an American [[hip hop music|hip hop]] recording artist and producer residing in [[Portland, Oregon]]. He was at the forefront of the new wave of [[underground hip hop|underground]] and [[alternative hip hop]] acts that emerged during the late 1990s and early 2000s. He was signed to [[El-P]]'s [[Definitive Jux]] label until it went on hiatus in 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/37778-definitive-jux-goes-on-hiatus/|title=Definitive Jux Goes "On Hiatus"|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=February 3, 2010|website=pitchfork.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-02-02}}</ref> betterPropaganda ranked him at number 19 at the ''Top 100 Artists of the Decade''.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://betterpropaganda.com/content.aspx?id=990|title=Top 100 Artists of the Decade|last=Taylor-Parker|first=Phillip|date=|work=|publisher=''betterPropaganda''|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100106084109/http://betterpropaganda.com/content.aspx?id=990|archive-date=January 6, 2010|via=|accessdate=December 21, 2011}}</ref>
He is a member of the groups [[The Weathermen (hip hop group)|The Weathermen]], [[Hail Mary Mallon]] (with [[Rob Sonic]] & DJ Big Wiz), [[The Uncluded]] (with [[Kimya Dawson]])<ref name=":0" /> and Two of Every Animal (with [[Cage (rapper)|Cage]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rhymesayers.com/hailmarymallon|title=Hail Mary Mallon|last=|first=|date=|website=rhymesayers.com|publisher=|language=en|access-date=2017-02-02}}</ref> Regarding his name, he said: "I acquired the name Aesop from a movie I had acted in with some friends. It was my character's name and it sort of stuck. The rock part came later just from throwing it in rhymes."<ref name="mvremix1">[http://www.mvremix.com/urban/interviews/aesoprock.shtml Aesop Rock Interview with MVRemix Urban | US and Canadian Underground Hip Hop and Soul – exclusive interviews, reviews, articles]. Mvremix.com. Retrieved on November 8, 2011.</ref>
==Early life and education==
===Early and personal life=== Bavitz was born at Syosset Hospital in [[Syosset, New York]] and raised in [[Northport, New York|Northport]], [[Long Island]], New York to his father Paul and mother Jameija.<ref>{{cite news | last = | first = | title = Aesop Rock – One of Four (Thank You) | work = | publisher= SongMeanings.com| url = http://www.songmeanings.net/songs/view/3530822107858559450/ | accessdate = December 21, 2011 }}</ref> Ian has two brothers: Christopher T. Bavitz<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hls.harvard.edu/faculty/directory/10055/Bavitz|title=Christopher T. Bavitz {{!}} Harvard Law School|last=School|first=Harvard Law|website=hls.harvard.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-04-21}}</ref> (born 1973), a clinical professor at [[Harvard Law School]] and director of Cyberlaw Clinic at the [[Berkman Klein Center for Internet & Society]], and Graham J. Bavitz (born 1978). Ian, along with his siblings, was raised [[Roman Catholic|Catholic]] but later on in his life became agnostic.<ref name="MVRemix">{{cite news | last =Doe| first =John| title = Aesop Rock: Laundry Days | work =Unknown | publisher= MVRemix.com| url = http://www.mvremix.com/urban/interviews/aesop_rock_06.shtml | accessdate = February 14, 2011 }}</ref> Bavitz attended [[Northport High School]] in 1990 and graduated in 1994. He married Allyson Baker, guitarist and vocalist of rock band [[Dirty Ghosts]] in 2005. They resided in San Francisco but have since divorced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://stickymagazine.com/features/interviews/736-dirty-ghosts |title=Talking Dirty: An Interview with Allyson Baker of Dirty Ghosts |author=Chad Hutchings |work=googleusercontent.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151114185010/http://stickymagazine.com/features/interviews/736-dirty-ghosts |archivedate=November 14, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref>
He has [[tattoos]] on each forearm. His left arm reads "Must Not Sleep..." and the right says "...Must Warn Others." These are inspired by childhood antics where he and his friends would act as robots arms outstretched quoting the line which has its origins in the 1956 film ''[[Invasion of the Body Snatchers (1956 film)|Invasion of the Body Snatchers]]''. Aesop Rock has used these quotes as lyrics in the chorus of his song "Commencement at the Obedience Academy": "Must not sleep; must warn others / Trust blocks creep where the dust storm hovers." He also used them in his song "Antisocial," in the line "Must not sleep; must warn others / I'll tourniquet your turbulence then trample on your stutters."
===1994–1998: College=== After graduating from high school, Bavitz attended [[Boston University]] in [[Massachusetts]] where he studied [[visual arts]].<ref name=firsttime>{{cite web|date=May 27, 2015|title=My First Time: Aesop Rock Remembers 1996|url=http://pigeonsandplanes.com/2015/05/my-first-time-aesop-rock-remembers-1996/|publisher=Pigeons & Planes|accessdate=27 May 2015}}</ref> He acquired his [[Bachelor of Fine Arts|bachelor's]] in 1998.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110117211713/http://www-test.bu.edu/alumni/informed/famous/arts/ Retrieved February 24, 2011]. Test.bu.edu. Retrieved on November 8, 2011.</ref> He met his future collaborator, [[Blockhead (music)|Blockhead]], in 1994 during the latter's only year at the school. After hearing Aesop Rock freestyle, Blockhead decided to forgo his own dreams of rapping in favor of focusing on production.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/blockhead/id5609495|title=iTunes - Music - Blockhead|work=apple.com}}</ref> Blockhead was involved with a crew in New York called The Overground that included [[Dub-L]].<ref name="Splendid Zine Interview">{{cite news|last=Miller |first=Walt |title=Love / Hate: Aesop Rock |work=Online Magazine |publisher=Splendid |url=http://www.splendidezine.com/features/aesop/ |accessdate=December 21, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101213203756/http://www.splendidezine.com/features/aesop/ |archivedate=December 13, 2010 |df= }}</ref> During his early adulthood, Aesop Rock held various odd jobs including positions answering phones for clothing catalogs, packaging artwork in [[art gallery]] storerooms and working for one-hour [[Photographic processing|photo developers]].<ref name=firsttime />
==Musical career==
===1985–2001: New York City underground music scene=== As a youth, Bavitz and his family would usually [[Commuting|commute]] to New York City. This had a great impact on him and the way he viewed the [[hip hop culture]]. Bavitz began rapping in the early 1990s. He cites [[Public Enemy (band)|Public Enemy]], [[Boogie Down Productions|BDP]], [[KMD]], and [[Run DMC]] as early influences.<ref name="mvremix1"/> Bavitz also listened to rock acts such as [[Dead Kennedys]], [[Fugazi]], and [[Ministry (band)|Ministry]]; he was introduced to these groups by his older brother Chris.<ref name="The Metabunker">{{cite web|title={{sic|Sie|ze|hide=y}} the Moment! Interview – Part II |url=http://www.metabunker.dk/?p=300 |publisher=The Metabunker |accessdate=December 21, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205231218/http://www.metabunker.dk/?p=300 |archivedate=February 5, 2012 }}</ref> Bavitz started to play instruments such as the piano and bass at an early age. He then eventually acquired a [[Sampler (musical instrument)|sampler]].<ref>{{cite web|title={{sic|Sie|ze|hide=y}} the Moment! Interview |url=http://www.metabunker.dk/?p=295 |publisher=The Metabunker |accessdate=December 21, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131162331/http://www.metabunker.dk/?p=295 |archivedate=January 31, 2012 }}</ref>
While attending college, Bavitz initially recorded and released two self-financed efforts, ''[[Music for Earthworms]]'' (1997), a full-length featuring [[underground hip hop|underground]] artist [[Percee P]] on two tracks. Bavitz also released a music video to "Abandon All Hope", which was one of the tracks on the CD. The album sold over 300 copies,<ref name="The Metabunker"/> largely from a grassroots internet-based promotion at his website AesopRock.com and then-popular web portal, MP3.com.<ref>[http://www.ootbot.com/archives/aesoprock/wormyhole/ AesopRock.com]. Retrieved on January 24, 2012.</ref> With the money he made from his previous release, he then released his ''[[Appleseed (EP)|Appleseed]]'' [[Extended play|EP]] in 1999 which received critical acclaim in the underground hip-hop circuit.{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} His early records were mostly produced by a long-time friend [[Blockhead (music)|Blockhead]], and underground producer [[Dub-L]].
After his breakthrough success in the underground hip hop and indie rap community, he was eventually noticed by the [[Mush (record label)|Mush]] label and obtained his first [[record deal]] in 1999, just a year after he graduated from college. Aesop released his first major album, ''[[Float (Aesop Rock album)|Float]]'' (2000), with guest appearances from [[Vast Aire]], [[Slug (rapper)|Slug]], and [[Dose One]]. Production was split between [[Blockhead (music)|Blockhead]] and Aesop himself, with one track by Omega One. During this time, Aesop worked at a photography [[Contemporary art gallery|gallery]].<ref name="AesopRockInterview">{{cite news|last=Kaplunk |first=Sumo |title=AES Interview |work=U.K. Hip-Hop |publisher=UKHH |url=http://www.mushrecords.com/articles/AesopRockUKHipHopProfile1.htm |date=August 15, 2000 |accessdate=December 21, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In August 2001 tragedy struck when Bavitz had a [[nervous breakdown]]. The song "One of Four" on his ''Daylight'' EP documents his struggles.<ref name="mrcomplex">{{cite news | last =Werde| first =Bill| title = Mr. Complex | work =[[Urb Magazine|URB]] | publisher= URB| url = http://www.mushrecords.com/articles/AesopRockUrbMrComplex.html | accessdate = May 17, 2010 }}</ref>
===2001–2004: ''Labor Days'', ''Daylight'' EP, ''Bazooka Tooth''=== Shortly after releasing ''Float'', Aesop Rock signed to [[Manhattan]]-based label [[Definitive Jux]] (commonly shortened to Def Jux), where he released ''[[Labor Days]]'' (2001), an album dedicated to the discussion of labor in American society and the concept of [[wage slavery|"wage slaves"]]. This album was most well known for its single "Daylight".{{Citation needed|date=January 2012}} Because of its popularity, ''[[Daylight (Aesop Rock album)|Daylight]]'' was re-released in 2002 as a seven-track EP, including an "alternative" new version of the song "Night Light", whose paraphrased lyrics simultaneously refer back to, and stand in stark opposition to, the original's. The song "Labor" (from ''Labor Days'') was featured in ''[[Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 4]]''; it also was the first album in his catalog to break through the ''Billboard'' charts, peaking at number 15 at the [[Billboard Top Independent Albums#Top Independent Albums|United States Independent Charts]]. [[Image:Aesop Rock live.jpg|220px|thumb|Aesop Rock performing live]]
''Labor Days'' was followed by ''[[Bazooka Tooth]]'' in 2003. For the first time, production was mostly handled by Rock himself, with three tracks from longtime collaborator [[Blockhead (music)|Blockhead]] and one from close friend and Definitive Jux label CEO El-P. Guest appearances include [[Party Fun Action Committee]], El-P, and [[Mr. Lif]] (all Definitive Jux labelmates) and [[Camp Lo]]. With this release Aesop hit a higher level of recognition, releasing "No Jumper Cables" as a single and music video, then another single, "Freeze", shortly after. A remix of "No Jumper Cables" was featured on ''[[Tony Hawk's Underground 2]]'', furthering Aesop's recognition. In 2004, he released ''[[Build Your Own Bazooka Tooth]]'' and created a contest in which you had to create a remix of an Aesop Rock song using the cappellas and instrumentals.
===2005–2007: ''Fast Cars'' EP, ''None Shall Pass'', Nike+iPod === In February 2005, Aesop Rock released a new EP, ''[[Fast Cars, Danger, Fire and Knives]]''. The first pressing of the EP included an 88-page booklet with lyrics from every release from ''Float'' until this EP (the lyric booklet is titled ''The Living Human Curiosity Sideshow''); later pressings of the album come without the booklet, but with an additional bonus track, "Facemelter". In addition, a limited number of albums were available direct from Def Jux with Aesop Rock's [[graffiti]] tag on them. In response to demands from his fans, Rock did less production on the EP: three songs are produced by Blockhead, three produced by Aesop, and one by [[Rob Sonic]]. During this time he was asked to join [[The Weathermen (hip-hop group)|The Weathermen]] to replace [[Vast Aire]].
Aesop Rock was commissioned to create a 45-minute instrumental track for the [[Nike+iPod]] running system, entitled ''All Day''. It was released in February 2007. Distributed via the [[iTunes Store|iTunes Music Store]] and featuring his wife Allyson Baker on guitar and [[turntablism|scratches]] from DJ Big Wiz, Aesop has described the release as "something that evolved enough that the sound was constantly fresh and attractive, as though the runner were moving through a set of differing cities or landscapes."<ref name="Podophile">{{cite web | url = http://podophile.com/2007/02/11/nike-aesop-rock-new-original-run-mix-this-tuesday/ | title = Nike+ Aesop Rock: New "Original Run" Mix This Tuesday | publisher = Podophile.com | date = February 11, 2007 | accessdate = March 21, 2007| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070312162411/http://podophile.com/2007/02/11/nike-aesop-rock-new-original-run-mix-this-tuesday/| archivedate= March 12, 2007 | deadurl= no}}</ref>
''All Day'' was followed in August of the same year by Bavitz's fifth full-length album, ''[[None Shall Pass]]'' released in 2007. The album also contained original artwork by [[Jeremy Fish]]. About Jeremy Fish, Aesop Rock said: "Man that guy is my hero. We have a friend in common who hit me up a while back saying that this guy Jeremy Fish had an opportunity to pitch a cartoon to Disney and wanted me to be involved in the music side. I flipped out cuz I was also a fan of his, and owned some of his work." Aesop Rock also teamed up with Jeremy Fish again in a project called Ghosts of the Barbary Coast. Aesop Rock made a song called "Tomorrow Morning", to go along with a slideshow of drawings that Jeremy Fish drew. This was displayed in San Francisco, but was also made available for download online.<ref>[http://www.fecalface.com/SF/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=213&Itemid=100 Aesop Rock Interview]. Fecalface.com. Retrieved on November 8, 2011.</ref> None Shall Pass had positive reviews from critics and fans, applauding Aesop for his change in sound.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hiphopdx.com/index/album-reviews/id.843/title.aesop-rock-none-shall-pass|title=Aesop Rock - None Shall Pass|first=HipHopDX -|last=http://hiphopdx.com|publisher=|accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref>
===2007–2011: Hiatus=== In February 2010, El-P announced that the label would be put "on hiatus," aside from selling its catalog and merchandise. During this time Bavitz was absent in terms of making any new albums or EPs, albeit being featured on other artist records and producing.
===2008–2013: Rhymesayers, HMM, Kimya Dawson, ''Skelethon''=== In 2009, Bavitz produced [[Felt (hip hop)|Felt's]] third album, ''[[Felt 3: A Tribute to Rosie Perez]]''.
April 20, 2011: it was announced that [[Rhymesayers Entertainment]] would release [[Hail Mary Mallon]]'s debut album ''Are You Going To Eat That?''. A music video for their first single off the album ''Smock'' was announced that same day.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://rhymesayers.com/news/rhymesayers_to_release_hail_mary_mallon_s_upcoming_album_are_you_gonna_eat_that_and_drops_first_sing | title = Rhymesayers Ent. Presents "Hail Mary Mallon" | publisher = Rhymesayers.com | accessdate = }}</ref>
November 2011: Bavitz announced via [[Reddit]] that he is working on his next solo album, and has a majority of it complete.<ref>{{cite web|title=I am Aesop Rock, [Ask Me Anything]|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/IAmA/comments/m3133/iama_aesop_rock_ama/c2xoq0s?context=3|publisher=Reddit|accessdate= November 7, 2011}}</ref>
December 2011: Aesop Rock was first reported to be working on an album with [[anti-folk]] singer [[Kimya Dawson]], famous for being one half of the group [[The Moldy Peaches]].<ref>{{cite web|title=@AesopRockWins|url=https://twitter.com/AesopRockWins/status/114265888332595203|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=September 16, 2011}}</ref> The [[working title]] for the project is called ''Hokey Fright''. The group has been named The Uncluded.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aesop Rock's Official Site|url=http://aesoprock.com/?p=564|publisher=Ian Bavitz|accessdate=December 20, 2011}}</ref>
January 17, 2012: it was reported that Aesop Rock finished recording his upcoming solo album ''[[Skelethon]]'', and it was scheduled to be released July 10, 2012 through Rhymesayers Entertainment.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aesop Rock Preps New LP|url=http://www.pitchfork.com/news/45139-aesop-rock-preps-new-lp-skelethon/|publisher=Pitchfork|accessdate= January 17, 2012}}</ref>
April 10, 2012: the first official single from Aesop Rock's Rhymesayers debut album ''Skelethon'', Zero Dark Thirty, was released on both SoundCloud and YouTube. As of April 20, 2012, the song had already received combined plays/views of 86,434.<ref>{{cite web|title=Zero Dark Thirty|url=http://aesoprock.com/?p=651|publisher=Aesop Rock|accessdate= April 20, 2012}}</ref> Skelethon was released on July 10, 2012.
February 11, 2013: the first music video from The Uncluded was released on YouTube, and the duo's first album ''Hokey Fright'' was released on May 7, 2013.<ref name=":0">[http://www.rhymesayers.com/theuncluded The Uncluded]. ''Rhymesayers Entertainment'', July 2, 2013.</ref> The album will consist of 16 tracks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Aesop Rock and Kimya Dawson Form Band the Uncluded, Announce Album, Share Video|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/49528-aesop-rock-and-kimya-dawson-form-band-the-uncluded-announce-album-share-video/|publisher=Pitchfork|accessdate= February 11, 2013}}</ref> The video for their third single "Delicate Cycle" has a [[Cameo appearance|cameo]] of [[Lil Bub]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uHYhzg8QWbI |title=The Uncluded – Delicate Cycle |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2013-05-20}}</ref>
===2013–present: Tour and ''The Impossible Kid''=== Aesop Rock toured the United States to promote ''Skelethon''.<ref name="NYMN September 2012">{{cite web |title=Aesop Rock Announces Final U.S. Dates of 2012 New York Music News |url=http://nymn.com/aesop-rock-announces-final-u-s-dates-of-2012-new-york-music-news/ |publisher=[[nymn.com]] |date=September 13, 2012 |accessdate=September 23, 2012}}</ref> Also, he has been touring with Kimya Dawson and performing material as The Uncluded.<ref name=":0" /> Along with playing a number of individual events, The Uncluded performed as part of a Rhymesayers lineup at Summerfest in Milwaukee, Wisconsin<ref>{{cite web|title=Rhymesayers Take over Summerfest 2013|publisher=Rhymesayers Entertainment|date=July 2, 2013|url=http://www.rhymesayers.com/news/rhymesayers_takes_over_summerfest_2013}}</ref> On the Skelethon tour, a majority of his touring equipment was stolen, prompting Aesop to raise funds by releasing limited edition artwork. It was announced he will be performing on the first day of Coachella 2013.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://showscoop.com/32506-Aesop-Rock |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130216184459/http://showscoop.com/32506-Aesop-Rock |dead-url=yes |archive-date=February 16, 2013 |title=Aesop Rock Tour |publisher=showscoop |accessdate=February 1, 2013 }}</ref>
In February 2016, Aesop Rock released a music video for the song "Rings" and announced his seventh studio album ''The Impossible Kid'', which was released on April 29, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Matera|first1=C. G.|title=Aesop Rock Returns With New Album ''The Impossible Kid'', Shares Trippy "Rings" Video|url=http://pitchfork.com/news/63600-aesop-rock-returns-with-new-album-the-impossible-kid-shares-trippy-rings-video/|accessdate=February 17, 2016|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|date=February 17, 2016}}</ref>
In 2017, Aesop Rock scored his first film soundtrack for [[Bushwick (film)|Bushwick]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/reviews/albums/aesop-rock-bushwick-original-motion-picture-soundtrack/|title=Aesop Rock: Bushwick (Original Motion Picture Soundtrack) Album Review - Pitchfork|website=pitchfork.com|accessdate=January 16, 2018}}</ref> A collaborative album with electronic musician [[Tobacco (musician)|Tobacco]] entitled ''Malibu Ken'' is scheduled to be released in January 2019.
==Lyrics== Bavitz's lyrics are generally seen as being both complex and abstract while others dismiss them as [[verbosity|verbose]]. His frequent use of [[homonym]]s exacerbates this. Critics state that the use of words can be so detailed that it becomes difficult to determine their originally intended meaning.<ref name="louispattison">{{cite news | last =Pattison | first =Louis | title = Aesop Rock's well-chosen words paint dense, fascinating pictures | work =[[BBC]] | publisher= BBC | date =August 1, 2007 | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/music/release/wvxm/ | accessdate = October 29, 2008 }}</ref> The lyrics are sometimes inspired by events which have occurred in Bavitz's personal life and are thus naturally prone to subjective interpretation by outsiders.<ref name="kimedward">{{cite news |last=Kim |first=Edward |title=Aesop Rock – Bazooka Tooth – Definitive Jux |work=[[Daily Nexus]] |publisher=dailynexus |date=November 7, 2003 |url=http://www.dailynexus.com/article.php?a=6025 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109211124/http://www.dailynexus.com/article.php?a=6025 |archivedate=January 9, 2009 |accessdate=November 30, 2011}}</ref><ref name="serenamarkstorm">{{cite news |last=Markstorm |first=Serena |title=Aesop Rock's well-chosen words paint dense, fascinating pictures |work=[[The Register-Guard]] |publisher=registerguard |year=2007 |url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Aesop+Rock%27s+well-chosen+words+paint+dense%2c+fascinating+pictures.-a0171259816 |accessdate=October 29, 2008 }}</ref>
Questioned about his lyrical style in an interview, Bavitz responded: <blockquote> "It’s probably because it’s not the most accessible music in the world. It may pose a slight challenge to the listener beyond your average pop song. I'm no genius by a long shot, but these songs are not nonsensical, that's pretty preposterous. I'd have to be a genius to pull this many nonsensical records over people's eyes. It's not exactly fast food but when people pretend I'm just spewing non-sequiturs and gibberish I can’t help but think they simply haven’t listened and are regurgitating some rumor they’ve heard about me. Even if it's not laid out in perfect sentences—is any rap?—you’d have to be an idiot to not at least grasp a few things from these songs. Or have had no interest in pulling anything from them in the first place."<ref name="guernicaarticle">{{cite news |last=DiPalo |first=Joseph |title=Graffiti or Vermeer |work=[[Guernica Magazine|Guernica]] |publisher=Guernica |date=September 2007 |url=http://www.guernicamag.com/interviews/397/graffiti_or_vermeer/ |accessdate=December 3, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205045610/http://www.guernicamag.com/interviews/397/graffiti_or_vermeer/ |archivedate=December 5, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref></blockquote>
In 2002 on the song "One of Four" (a hidden track on the ''[[Daylight (Aesop Rock album)|Daylight]]'' EP) Aesop Rock explains: <blockquote> "But I can tell you that I only write shit down when I believe it / so take this how you want but know I mean it."<br /> — Aesop Rock, "One of Four" ''[[Daylight (Aesop Rock album)|Daylight]]'' EP (2002) </blockquote>
In May 2014, a study by Matt Daniels found that Aesop Rock's vocabulary in his music surpassed 85 other major hip-hop and rap artists, as well as Shakespeare's works and Herman Melville's Moby Dick, being named the largest vocabulary in Hip Hop.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://poly-graph.co/vocabulary.html|title=Rappers, sorted by the size of their vocabulary|last=Daniels|first=Matt|date=|website=|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-09}}</ref> An updated, to-scale view of this study was subsequently done by Mike Pultz.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Largest Vocabulary in Hip Hop (Adjusted)|url=http://mikepultz.com/number-of-unique-words-used-within-artists-first-35000-lyrics-adjusted/|publisher=Mike Pultz|accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref> To build up his vocabulary, he reads a lot of news and science articles and writes down all the words he finds interesting.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Simmons|first1=Jon|title=Interview: Aesop Rock|url=http://soundofboston.com/interview-aesop-rock/|website=Sound of Boston|accessdate=10 February 2015}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|Aesop Rock discography}}{{See also|Hail Mary Mallon#Discography|The Uncluded#Discography||l1=Hail Mary Mallon discography|l2=The Uncluded discography|l3=}} * ''[[Music for Earthworms]]'' (1997) * ''[[Float (Aesop Rock album)|Float]]'' (2000) * ''[[Labor Days]]'' (2001) * ''[[Bazooka Tooth]]'' (2003) * ''[[None Shall Pass]]'' (2007) * ''[[Skelethon]]'' (2012) * ''[[The Impossible Kid (album)|The Impossible Kid]]'' (2016)

{{redirect|AKAA|the Finnish town|Akaa}}
[[File:Akaa logo.png|{{largethumb}}|Logo for the Aga Khan Award for Architecture]] The '''Aga Khan Award for Architecture''' ('''AKAA''') is an [[List of architecture prizes|architectural prize]] established by [[Aga Khan IV]] in 1977. It aims to identify and reward [[architecture|architectural]] concepts that successfully address the needs and aspirations of [[Muslim world|Islamic societies]] in the fields of contemporary [[design]], [[social housing]], [[community development]] and improvement, [[Building restoration|restoration]], [[reuse]] and [[Architectural conservation|area conservation]], as well as [[landscape design]] and [[Environmental science|improvement of the environment]].<ref name="ArcWeek">"[http://www.architectureweek.com/2002/0109/news_1-1.html Aga Khan Award for Architecture]." ''ArchitectureWeek'' 9 Jan. 2002.</ref> It is presented in three-year cycles to multiple projects and has a monetary award, with prizes totalling [[United States dollar|US$]] 1 million.<ref>^[http://www.canadianarchitect.com/news/aga-khan-award-for-architecture-prize-doubled-to-us-1-million/1001116410/ ''Canadian Architect'', April 26, 2012.]</ref> Uniquely among architectural awards, it recognizes projects, teams, and stakeholders in addition to buildings and people.<ref name="ArcWeek"/>
The award is associated with the [[Aga Khan Trust for Culture]] (AKTC), an agency of the [[Aga Khan Development Network]] (AKDN).
==Award process== The award is aimed at societies in which Muslims have a significant presence.<ref name="ArcWeek"/> It is organised on the basis of a three-year cycle and is governed by a steering committee chaired by the Aga Khan IV.<ref name="CanadianArc">{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianarchitect.com/news/aga-khan-award-for-architecture-announces-master-jury-for-2007/1000060192/|title=Aga Khan Award for Architecture announces Master Jury for 2007 - Canadian Architect|date=12 January 2007|publisher=}}</ref>
A new committee is constituted each cycle to establish the eligibility criteria for projects, provide thematic direction with reference to current concerns, and to develop plans for the long-term future of the award. The ''Steering Committee'' is responsible for the selection of the ''Master Jury'' appointed for each award cycle, and for activities such as [[seminar]]s and field visits, the [[award ceremony]], publications and exhibitions.
===Chairman's Award=== The ''Chairman's Award'' is given in honour of accomplishments that fall outside the mandate of the Master Jury. It recognises lifetime achievements. It has been presented four times: in 1980 to Egyptian architect and urban planner [[Hassan Fathy]],<ref>[http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/firstcycle/chairman.html Lifetime Achievements of Hassan Fathy] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208004014/http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/firstcycle/chairman.html |date=February 8, 2012 }}</ref> in 1986 to Iraqi architect and educator [[Rifat Chadirji]],<ref>[http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/thirdcycle/thirdcycle_chairman.html Lifetime Achievements of Rifat Chadirji] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208004020/http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/thirdcycle/thirdcycle_chairman.html |date=February 8, 2012 }}</ref> in 2001 to [[Sri Lanka]]n architect [[Geoffrey Bawa]],<ref>[http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/eighthcycle/bawa.htm Lifetime Achievements of Geoffrey Bawa] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140219135634/http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/eighthcycle/bawa.htm |date=February 19, 2014 }}</ref> and in 2010 to historian of Islamic art and architecture [[Oleg Grabar]].<ref name="Grabar">{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/Content/1037|title=Speech by Oleg Grabar, Recipient of the 2010 Chairman's Award - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref>
===Promotion=== The Aga Khan Foundation funded the television series ''Architects on the Frontline'' which was about entries to the competition. The media watchdog [[Ofcom]] criticised [[BBC World News]] for breaking United Kingdom broadcasting rules with the series, which praised the competition; viewers were not informed that it was sponsored content.<ref>{{cite news|website=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-33971919|title=News channels breached sponsorship rules, Ofcom says|date=18 August 2015|access-date=18 August 2015}}</ref>
==Award cycles== Prizes totalling up to US$ 1m, constituting the largest architectural award in the world,<ref name="ArcWeek"/> are presented every three years to projects selected by the Master Jury.<ref name="CanadianArc"/> Since 1977, documentation has been compiled on over 7500 building projects located throughout the world, of which over 100 projects have received awards.<ref name="CanadArc2013"/>
===First (1978-1980)=== [[File:Kuwaittowers.jpg|thumb|[[Kuwait Towers|Water Towers]], [[Kuwait City]]]]
The 1980 award ceremony took place at the [[Shalimar Gardens (Lahore)|Shalimar Gardens]] in [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]]. During this cycle, the Chairman's Award was given to [[Hassan Fathy]] in recognition of his lifelong commitment to architecture in the [[Muslim world]]. Prominent architect [[Muzharul Islam]] was a member of the Master Jury of the first Aga Khan Award for Architecture.
Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1980|title=1980 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Kampung Improvement Programme, [[Jakarta]], Indonesia *Pondok Pesantren Pabelan, Central Java, Indonesia *Ertegün House, [[Bodrum]], Turkey *[[Turkish Historical Society]], [[Ankara]], Turkey *Mughal Sheraton Hotel, [[Agra]], India *Conservation of [[Sidi Bou Said|Sidi Bou Saïd]], [[Tunis]], Tunisia *Rüstem Pasa Caravanserai, [[Edirne]], Turkey *[[Qatar National Museum|National Museum]], [[Doha]], Qatar *[[Ālī Qāpū|Ali Qapu]], Chehel Sutun, and [[Hasht Behesht]], [[Isfahan]], Iran *[[Halawa House]], Agamy, Egypt *Medical Centre, [[Mopti]], Mali *Courtyard Houses, [[Agadir]], Morocco *[[Kuwait Towers|Water Towers]], [[Kuwait City]], Kuwait *Intercontinental Hotel and Conference Centre, [[Mecca]], Saudi Arabia, by [[Rolf Gutbrod]] and [[Frei Otto]] *Agricultural Training Centre, [[Nianing]], Senegal
<gallery> File:TerrasseSiBouSaid.JPG|Conservation of Sidi Bou Saïd, Tunis </gallery>
===Second (1981-1983)=== The 1983 award ceremony took place at the [[Topkapı Palace]] in [[Istanbul]]. Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1983|title=1983 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *[[Great Mosque of Niono]], [[Mali]] *[[Šerefudin's White Mosque]], [[Visoko, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Visoko]], Bosnia and Herzegovina *[[Ramses Wissa Wassef]] Arts Centre, [[Giza]], Egypt *[[Nail Çakirhan Residence]], [[Akyaka, Muğla|Akyaka Village]], [[Muğla]], Turkey *[[Hafsia Quarter I]], Tunis, Tunisia *[[Tanjong Jara Beach Hotel]] and [[Rantau Abang Visitors' Centre]], [[Kuala Terengganu]], Malaysia *[[Résidence Andalous]], [[Sousse]], Tunisia *Hajj Terminal, [[King Abdulaziz International Airport]], [[Jeddah]], Saudi Arabia, by [[Fazlur Khan]] *[[Mausoleums of Multan|Tomb of Shah Rukn-i-'Alam]], [[Multan]], Pakistan *[[Darb Qirmiz Quarter]], [[Cairo]], Egypt *[[Azem Palace]], [[Damascus]], Syria
<gallery> File:NailCakirhanHouse AkyakaMuglaTurkey 1983AghaKhanArchitectureAward.jpg|Nail Çakirhan Residence, Akyaka Village, Turkey File:Shahrukne Alam.jpg|Mausoleum of Shah Rukn-i-Alam in Multan, Pakistan File:DamascusAzemPalaceLargeCrtyd.jpg|Azem Palace, Damascus, Syria File:Hajj Terminal 01 Jeddah.jpg|Hajj Terminal </gallery>
===Third (1984-1986)=== [[File:Mostar Old Town Panorama.jpg|thumb|[[Mostar|Mostar Old Town]]]]
The 1986 award ceremony took place at [[El Badi Palace]] in [[Marrakesh]], [[Morocco]]. The [[Brief (architecture)|brief]] prepared by the Steering Committee for this award cycle focused on the preservation and continuation of cultural heritage, community building and social housing, and excellence in contemporary architectural expression.
Six winners were chosen from among 213 entries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/198706/the.changing.present.htm |title=The Changing Present, Loughran, G., Saudi Aramco World, Nov/Dec 1987: 28-37 |accessdate=2006-12-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061229124620/http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/198706/the.changing.present.htm| archivedate= 29 December 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The conservation of Mostar Old Town and restoration of Al-Aqsa Mosque were examples of cultural heritage, the first theme, while the Yama Mosque and Bhong Mosque were noted for their innovation in translating traditional techniques and materials to meet contemporary requirements. The Social Security Complex and Dar Lamane Housing address the issues of community and social housing while remaining sensitive to local culture. The Chairman's Award for Lifetime Achievements was given to [[Iraq]]i architect [[Rifat Chadirji]].
Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1986|title=1986 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Social Security Complex, Istanbul, Turkey *Dar Lamane Housing, [[Casablanca]], Morocco *[[Mostar|Conservation of Mostar Old Town]], Bosnia and Herzegovina<ref>[http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/thirdcycle/bosnia.html (AKTC)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208004027/http://www.akdn.org/agency/akaa/thirdcycle/bosnia.html |date=February 8, 2012 }} [http://archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.tcl?site_id=699 (ArchNet)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060208094714/http://archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.tcl?site_id=699 |date=February 8, 2006 }}</ref> *[[Al-Aqsa Mosque|Restoration of Al-Aqsa Mosque]], [[Temple Mount|Noble Sanctuary]], [[Jerusalem]] *[[Yaama Mosque]], Yaama, [[Tahoua]], Niger *[[Bhong Mosque]], [[Bhong]], [[Rahim Yar Khan District]], Pakistan <gallery> File:Jerusalem Al-Aqsa Mosque BW 2010-09-21 06-38-12.JPG|Restoration of Al-Aqsa Mosque, Jerusalem <!-- Deleted image removed: File:BhongMosque.jpg|Bhong Mosque, Pakistan --> </gallery>
===Fourth (1987-1989)=== [[File:Sangshad inside.jpg|thumb|[[Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban|National Assembly Building]], [[Dhaka]]]]
The 1989 award ceremony took place at the [[Citadel of Salah Ed-Din]] in Cairo. The fourth cycle of the award considered 241 project nominations. Of these, 32 were short-listed for technical review<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/198906/better.by.design.htm |title=Better by Design, Loughran, G., Saudi Aramco World, Nov/Dec 1989: 28-33 |accessdate=2006-12-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061229121526/http://www.saudiaramcoworld.com/issue/198906/better.by.design.htm| archivedate= 29 December 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and the Master Jury selected 11 winners. Two themes were noted as areas of focus in this cycle: Revival of past vernacular traditions, and projects that reflect the efforts of individual patrons and of non-governmental organisations in improving society.
Projects such as the Great Omari Mosque and the Rehabilitation of Asilah seek to reconstruct and preserve heritage buildings for continued use, demonstrating the significance of these spaces within their communities. Meanwhile, the Grameen Bank Housing Programme and Sidi el-Aloui Primary School apply architectural solutions to address current socioeonomic issues.
Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1989|title=1989 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Great Omari Mosque ([[Sidon]], [[Lebanon]]) *Rehabilitation of [[Asilah]] (Asilah, Morocco) *[[Grameen Bank|Grameen Bank Housing Programme]] (various locations in [[Bangladesh]]) *Citra Niaga Urban Development ([[Samarinda]], [[East Kalimantan]], Indonesia) *Gürel Family Summer Residence ([[Çanakkale]], [[Turkey]]) *Hayy Assafarat Landscaping and al-Kindi Plaza ([[Riyadh]], Saudi Arabia) *Sidi el-Aloui Primary School (Tunis, Tunisia) *Corniche Mosque (Jeddah, Saudi Arabia) *Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Riyadh, Saudi Arabia) *[[Jatiya Sangsad Bhaban|National Assembly Building]] ([[Sher-e-Bangla Nagar]], [[Dhaka]], [[Bangladesh]]), by [[Louis Kahn]] *[[Arab World Institute|Institut du Monde Arabe]] (Paris, France), by [[Jean Nouvel]] and [[Architecture-Studio]]
<gallery> File:Assilah Waterfront2.jpg|Asilah Waterfront File:Jatiyo Sangshad Bhaban (Roehl).jpg|National Assembly of Bangladesh, Dhaka </gallery>
===Fifth (1990-1992)=== The 1992 award ceremony took place at the [[Registan|Registan Square]] in [[Samarkand]], [[Uzbekistan]]. Uzbek government also released a postal stamp to commemorate the award ceremony & restoration of Registan Square in Partnership with Aga Khan Trust for Culture. [[File:EDI Panorama Ahmedabad.JPG|thumb|Entrepreneurship Development Institute of India]]
Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1992|title=1992 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *[[Kairouan]] Conservation Programme (Kairouan, Tunisia) *Palace Parks Programme (Istanbul, [[Turkey]]) *[[Cultural Park for Children, Egypt|Cultural Park for Children]] (Cairo, Egypt) *[[East Wahdat, Amman|East Wahdat]] Upgrading Programme ([[Amman]], [[Jordan]]) *[[Kampung Kali Code]] ([[Yogyakarta]], Indonesia) *Stone Building System ([[Daraa Governorate]], Syria) *[[Demir Holiday Village]] ([[Bodrum]], Turkey) *[[Pan African Institute for Development]] ([[Ouagadougou]], [[Burkina Faso]]), by [[Association pour le Développement d'une Architecture et d'un Urbanisme Africains]] (A.D.A.U.A. - Association for the Development of African Architecture and Urban Planning) *[[Entrepreneurship Development Institute of India]] ([[Ahmedabad]], [[India]]), by [[Bimal Patel|Bimal Hasmukh Patel]]
<gallery> File:TUNISIE KAIROUAN 01.jpg|Kairouan </gallery>
===Sixth (1993-1995)=== The 1995 award ceremony took place at the [[Surakarta Sunanate#Residences|Kraton Surakarta]] in [[Surakarta]], Indonesia. [[File:KaediRegionalHospital2.JPG|thumb|Kaédi Regional Hospital]]
Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1995|title=1995 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Restoration of [[Bukhara]] Old City (Bukhara, Uzbekistan) *Conservation of Old [[San'a']] (San'a', [[Yemen]]) *[[Hafsia]] Quarter II (Tunis, Tunisia) *[[Khuda-ki-Basti]] Incremental Development Scheme ([[Hyderabad, Pakistan|Hyderabad]], Pakistan) *Aranya Community Housing ([[Indore]], India), by B.V. Doshi <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/project.asp?id=1242|title=Aranya Community Housing - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Great Mosque and Redevelopment of the Old City Centre (Riyadh, Saudi Arabia) *[[Menara Mesiniaga]] ([[Kuala Lumpur]], [[Malaysia]]) *[[Kaédi Regional Hospital]] ([[Kaedi]], [[Mauritania]]), by [[A.D.A.U.A.]] *Mosque of the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey|Grand National Assembly]] ([[Ankara]], Turkey) *[[Alliance Franco-Sénégalaise]] ([[Kaolack]], [[Senegal]]) *Re-Forestation Programme of the [[Middle East Technical University]] (Ankara, Turkey) *Landscaping Integration of the [[Soekarno-Hatta International Airport|Soekarno-Hatta Airport]] ([[Cengkareng]], Indonesia)
<gallery> File:2012 Bukhara 7515821196.jpg|Bukhara Old City File:San'a03 flickr.jpg|San'a' File:Menara Mesiniaga aerial view.jpg|Menara Mesiniaga </gallery>
===Seventh (1996-1998)=== The 1998 award ceremony took place at the [[Alhambra]] in [[Granada]], [[Spain]]. The Master Jury selected seven winning projects of the 424 presented. During this cycle, special emphasis was placed on projects that responded creatively to the emerging forces of [[globalization]]. Issues such as [[demographic pressure]], [[environmental degradation]], and the crisis of the [[nation-state]], and the changes in lifestyle, cultural values, and relationships among social groups and between governments and people at large they prompted, were considered.
Of the winning projects, the rehabilitation of Hebron Old Town and Slum Networking of Indore City sought to reclaim community space in environments strained by social, physical and environmental degradation. The Lepers Hospital created a sustainable and dignified shelter for a marginalized segment of society. The remaining projects were recognized for their contribution in evolving an architectural vocabulary in response to contemporary social and environmental challenges.<ref>{{cite book |editor=Cynthia C. Davidson |title=Legacies for the Future: Contemporary Architecture in Islamic Societies |year=1999 |publisher=Thames and Hudson Ltd. |location=New York |isbn=0-500-28087-8}}</ref>
[[File:Alhamra Art Centre.JPG|thumb|Alhamra Arts Council]] Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=1998|title=1998 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Rehabilitation of [[Hebron]] Old Town *[[Slum Networking]] of Indore, India *Lepers Hospital, Chopda Taluka, India *Salinger Residence, [[Bangi, Malaysia|Bangi]], [[Selangor]], Malaysia *[[Tuwaiq Palace]], [[Riyadh]], Saudi Arabia *[[Alhamra Arts Council]], [[Lahore]], Pakistan, by [[Nayyar Ali Dada]] *[[Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly|Vidhan Bhavan]], [[Bhopal]], India<ref>[http://archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.tcl?site_id=1759 Vidhan Bhavan, (ArchNet)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060208103213/http://archnet.org/library/sites/one-site.tcl?site_id=1759 |date=2006-02-08 }}</ref>
<gallery> File:Hébron.JPG|Hebron </gallery>
===Eighth (1999-2001)=== [[File:GD-EG-Musée Nubien001.JPG|thumb|Nubian Museum, Aswan]]
The 2001 Award Presentation Ceremony took place at the [[Citadel of Aleppo]] in [[Syria]]. During this cycle, the Chairman's Award was given to [[Geoffrey Bawa]] to honour and celebrate his lifetime achievements in and contribution to the field of architecture.
Award recipients:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=2001|title=2001 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *New Life for Old Structures (various locations, [[Iran]]) *[[Aït Iktel]] ([[Abadou]], Morocco) *[[Kahere Eila Poultry Farming School]] ([[Koliagbe]], [[Guinea]]) *[[Nubian Museum]] ([[Aswan]], Egypt) *[[SOS Children's Villages|SOS Children's Village]] ([[Aqaba]], Jordan) *[[Olbia Social Centre]] of [[Akdeniz University]] ([[Antalya]], Turkey), by [[Cengiz Bektas]] *[[Bagh-e-Ferdowsi]] ([[Tehran]], Iran) *[[Datai Hotel]] ([[Langkawi]], Malaysia)
<gallery> File:Aswan Nubian Museum entrance.jpg|Nubian Museum, Aswan </gallery>
===Ninth (2002-2004)=== The 2004 award ceremony took place at the [[Humayun's Tomb]] in [[New Delhi]], India. During the ninth cycle, 378 projects were nominated. Of these, 23 were site-reviewed, and the Master Jury selected seven award recipients.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caroun.com/Architecture/AgaKhan/z4-AgaKhan-2004.html |title=Aga Khan Award for Architecture 2004 - Architecture & Urbanism magazine, No. 78/79, Autumn/Winter 2005, Tehran |accessdate=2006-12-06| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061202065012/http://www.caroun.com/Architecture/AgaKhan/z4-AgaKhan-2004.html| archivedate= 2 December 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Notable among the recipients are the ''Sandbag Shelter Prototypes'', developed by [[Nader Khalili]] to enable victims of natural disasters and war to build their own [[Refugee shelter|shelter]] using earth-filled sandbags and barbed wire. The resulting structures - made up of arches, domes and vaulted spaces built using [[superadobe]] techniques - provide earthquake resistance, shelter from hurricanes and flood resistance, while being aesthetically pleasing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/akaa_award9_awards_detail3.asp|title=Sandbag Shelters - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> [[File:Petronas Panorama II.jpg|thumb|Petronas Towers, Kuala Lumpur]]
Other winning projects include a primary school in [[List of cities in Burkina Faso|Gando]], [[Burkina Faso]], that combines high-caliber architectural design with local materials, techniques and community participation. The Bibliotheca Alexandria in Egypt and the Petronas Towers in Malaysia are examples of high-profile landmark buildings.
Award recipients:<ref>[http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=2004 2004 Cycle Awards Recipients] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130521082333/http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=2004 |date=May 21, 2013 }}</ref> *[[Bibliotheca Alexandrina]], Alexandria, Egypt, by [[Norway|Norwegian]] architectural office [[Snøhetta (company)|Snøhetta]] *Primary School, [[List of cities in Burkina Faso|Gando]], [[Burkina Faso]], by [[Diébédo Francis Kéré]] *''Sandbag Shelter Prototypes'' (various locations), developed by [[Nader Khalili]] *Restoration of Al-Abbas Mosque (Asnaf, Yemen) *[[Old City of Jerusalem Revitalisation Programme]], Jerusalem *B2 House, [[Ayvacık, Çanakkale|Ayvacik]], Turkey, by [[Han Tümertekin]] *[[Petronas Towers]], [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia, by [[César Pelli]]
<gallery> File:Flickr - DVIDSHUB - New eco-dome signals changes for local village (Image 10 of 10).jpg|''Eco-Dome''<ref>See [http://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?search=eco+dome&title=Special%3ASearch more construction images] in [[Wikimedia Commons]]</ref> sandbag shelter under construction in [[Djibouti]], May 2012 File:Bibliotheca Alexandrina plaza 003.jpg|Bibliotheca Alexandrina File:Gando-School-Burkina-Faso.JPG|Primary School in Gando File:Old city of Jerusalem.jpg|Old city of Jerusalem File:View on Petronas Towers.JPG|Petronas Towers within Kuala Lumpur cityscape </gallery>
===Tenth (2005-2007)=== The 2007 Award Presentation Ceremony was held at the Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. This cycle marked the 30th anniversary of the award. A total of 343 projects were presented for consideration, and 27 were reviewed on site by international experts.<ref name="PRAkaa20070904">{{cite press release |title=Nine Projects Receive 2007 Aga Khan Award for Archicture |publisher=[[Aga Khan Development Network]] (AKDN) |date=2007-09-04 |url=http://akdn.org/news/2007September4.htm |accessdate=2007-09-06 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070910040413/http://www.akdn.org/news/2007September4.htm| archivedate= 10 September 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The award recipients were:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=2007|title=2007 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> *Samir Kassir Square, [[Beirut]], Lebanon *Rehabilitation of the City of [[Shibam]], Yemen *Central Market, [[Koudougou]], Burkina Faso *[[Universiti Teknologi Petronas|University of Technology Petronas]], [[Seri Iskandar|Bandar Seri Iskandar]], Malaysia, by [[Foster + Partners]] *Restoration of the [[Amiriya Madrasa]], [[Rada, Yemen]] *Moulmein Rise Residential Tower, [[Singapore]], by [[WOHA]] Architects *Royal Netherlands Embassy, [[Addis Ababa]], Ethiopia, by [[Dick Van Gameren]], [[Bjarne Mastenbroek]] *Rehabilitation of the Walled City, [[Nicosia]], Cyprus *[[METI Handmade School|METI School]] in [[Rudrapur, Bangladesh|Rudrapur]], [[Dinajpur District, Bangladesh|Dinajpur]], Bangladesh, by [[Anna Heringer]]
<gallery> File:Solidare, Beirut.jpg|Samir Kassir Square in [[Beirut Central District]] File:Shibam Wadi Hadhramaut Yemen.jpg|Shibam |University of Technology Petronas File:Utphishot.JPG|University of Technology Petronas File:Jennifer Bryson in Yemen.jpg|Amiriya Madrasa File:Nicosia Buyuk Han 02.jpg|[[Büyük Han]], Nicosia </gallery>
===Eleventh (2008-2010)=== [[File:Wadi Hanifa from King Fahd Rd.jpg|thumb|Wadi Hanifa]]
The 2010 Award Presentation Ceremony was held at the [[Museum of Islamic Art, Doha]]. A total of 401 projects were nominated of which 19 were shortlisted.<ref>[http://archrecord.construction.com/news/daily/archives/2010/11/101124aga_khan.asp Jenna M. McKnight: ''Revealed: Winners of 2010 Aga Khan Award for Architecture'', in the Architectural Record, November 24, 2010], retrieved 1 December 2010</ref>
The Chairman's Award went to [[Oleg Grabar]].<ref name="Grabar"/>
The award recipients were:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.akdn.org/architecture/awards.asp?tri=2010|title=2010 Cycle - Aga Khan Development Network|website=www.akdn.org}}</ref> * [[Wadi Hanifa]] Project, Riyadh, [[Saudi Arabia]] * Revitalisation of nineteenth and early twentieth-century architectural heritage of [[Tunis]], [[Tunisia]] * Research Centre and Museum, [[Madinat Al-Zahra]], Cordoba, [[Spain]], by [[Nieto Sobejano Arquitectos]]<ref>[http://www.dezeen.com/2009/12/16/museum-and-research-centre-madinat-al-zahra-by-nieto-sobejano-arquitectos/ Article on the project by the architects, Enrique Sobejano and Fuensanta Nieto]</ref> * [[Ipekyol Textile Factory]], [[Edirne]], [[Turkey]] * Bridge School, [[Xiashi]], [[Fujian]], [[China]] <gallery> File:അൽ എൽബ് അണക്കെട്ട്.JPG|Al Elb Dam, Wadi Hanifa File:Cathedral of St. Vincent de Paul.jpg|[[Cathedral of St. Vincent de Paul]], Tunis, 1897 File:Theatre Municipal de Tunis.jpg|Municipal Theatre, Tunis, by [[Jean Emile Resplandy]], 1902 File:Centro de interpretación de Madinat Al-Zahra (Córdoba, Spain).jpg|Madinat Al-Zahra, Spain File:Centro de interpretación de Madinat Al-Zahra (Córdoba, España).jpg|Madinat Al-Zahra, Spain </gallery>
===Twelfth (2011-2013)=== [[File:Carpet Bazaar of Tabriz.JPG|thumb|Tabriz Bazaar]]
20 projects were shortlisted for the ceremony held in Lisbon in September 2013.<ref name="CanadArc2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.canadianarchitect.com/news/twenty-projects-shortlisted-for-1-million-aga-khan-award-for-architecture/1002305779/|title=Twenty projects shortlisted for $1-million Aga Khan Award for Architecture - Canadian Architect|date=11 May 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>[http://www.worldarchitecturenews.com/index.php?fuseaction=wanappln.showbriefdetail&newsid=1932 World Architecture News], retrieved 6 May 2013</ref>
The winning projects are:<ref>Cathleen McGuigan: [http://archrecord.construction.com/news/2013/09/130906-Aga-Kahn-Awards-Announced.asp "Aga Khan Awards Go to Projects that Build Community"], in ''The Architectural Record'', 6 September 2013</ref><ref>Aga Khan Award for Architecture [http://www.akdn.org/Architecture/2013recipients.asp#4438 2013 Cycle Award Recipients]</ref> * [[Emergency (NGO)|Emergency]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emergency.it/|title=Emergency - Sito Ufficiale - Home|first=Idea Futura srl -|last=www.ideafutura.com|website=www.emergency.it}}</ref> Salam Centre for Cardiac Surgery,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.salamcentre.emergency.it/|title=The Salam Centre for Cardiac Surgery - Home page|website=www.salamcentre.emergency.it}}</ref> [[Khartoum]], [[Sudan]], by Italian practice [[Studio Tamassociati]], completed in 2010 * Revitalisation of Birzeit Historic Centre, [[Birzeit]], Palestine * Hassan II Bridge, [[Rabat]], [[Morocco]] * Rehabilitation of [[Tabriz Bazaar]], [[Tabriz]], Iran * [[:de:Islamischer Friedhof Altach|Islamic Cemetery]], [[Altach]], [[Austria]], by Austrian architect [[:de:Bernardo Bader|Bernardo Bader]], inaugurated in 2012

{{primary sources|date=June 2011}} '''Alliance Graphique Internationale''' (AGI) is a club of the world’s leading [[graphic artist]]s and [[designer]]s. There are 497 members from 39 countries. Its members have been collectively responsible for the identity design of most of the world's top corporations and institutions as well as for countless examples of globally known packaging, publications, illustration and posters. [[:fr:Bernard_Baissait|Bernard Baissait]] is the only member who left the AGI following disagreement.<ref>http://www.bernardbaissait.fr/cv.php</ref>
== History == In 1951 two Swiss and three French graphic artists decided to formalise their relationship into a kind of association. In 1952 the Alliance Graphique Internationale was incorporated in [[Paris]] with 65 members. The first AGI show was in [[Paris]] in 1955. In 1969 the AGI headquarters moved to [[Zürich]].<ref>[http://www.a-g-i.org/about/about_who.php?show=3 AGI Backwards]</ref>
The most important events of the organisation are the annual AGI Congress and AGI Open that take place in a different country in each year.<ref>[http://www.a-g-i.org/about/about_who.php?show=2 AGI Outwards]</ref>
